verses.text: Remember your Creator in the days of your youth, before the days of trouble come and the years approach when you will say, 'I find no pleasure in them.'
verses.comment: The call to remember the Creator early in life is literal, but also hints at a spiritual return to God before worldly cares overwhelm the soul. Classic Christian tradition interprets this as an exhortation to lifelong devotion, not just fleeting youthful zeal.

verses.text: Before the sun and the light, the moon and the stars grow dark, and the clouds return after the rain.
verses.comment: The diminishing of the sun, moon, and stars is a poetic image for declining vigor and approaching death. Spiritually, it anticipates the fading of earthly joys, calling us to set our ultimate hope beyond this life.

verses.text: In the day when the keepers of the house tremble, and the strong men stoop; when the grinders cease because they are few, and those looking through the windows grow dim;
verses.comment: Symbolic language: the 'keepers' are hands, 'strong men' are legs, 'grinders' are teeth, 'windows' are eyes—all fading with age. This reminds us of the dignity of the whole human person and the need to prepare spiritually for the inevitability of death.

verses.text: When the doors to the street are shut and the sound of grinding fades; when people rise up at the sound of a bird, but all their songs grow faint;
verses.comment: Continuing the allegory of aging, diminished senses signal the approach of the end. Saintly tradition sees in this a call to keep spiritual watchfulness, even when the body weakens.

verses.text: when people are afraid of heights, and terrors along the way; when the almond tree blossoms, the grasshopper drags itself along, and desire fails—because man goes to his eternal home, and the mourners go about the streets.
verses.comment: These vivid images show the weakness of old age before returning 'to his eternal home'—a subtle nod to an afterlife. The eternal home hints at a fuller destiny beyond this world.

verses.text: Remember him before the silver cord is snapped, and the golden bowl is broken; before the pitcher is shattered at the spring or the wheel broken at the well.
verses.comment: These metaphors—cord, bowl, pitcher, wheel—speak of the fragility of life, urging us to cling to our Creator before death comes. Remembrance is both active faith and confidence in divine providence.

verses.text: And the dust returns to the earth as it was, and the spirit returns to God who gave it.
verses.comment: Echoes Genesis 2:7—the body returns to 'dust,' but the soul returns to God. Both literal death and the promise of divine judgment are implied. Jesus confirms in Matthew 10:28 the distinction of body and soul.

verses.text: 'Vanity of vanities,' says the Preacher; 'All is vanity.'
verses.comment: Refrain from the start of the book, summing up the fleetingness of earthly endeavors. This prepares the reader for the need for eternal hope and real treasures that do not fade (cf. Matthew 6:19–21).

verses.text: Because the Preacher was wise, he taught the people knowledge; he pondered, searched out, and arranged many proverbs.
verses.comment: The deliberate teaching ministry here mirrors the tradition of passing on divine wisdom through authorized interpreters—a foreshadowing of structured teaching offices in the Church.

verses.text: The Preacher sought to find words of delight, and he wrote words of truth uprightly.
verses.comment: Pursuing beauty and truth in teaching echoes how Scripture combines inspiration and literary form. The use of carefully chosen words shows respect for divine revelation communicated faithfully.

verses.text: The words of the wise are like goads, and like firmly fixed nails; they are given by one Shepherd.
verses.comment: The 'one Shepherd' statement is significant; in later revelation, Jesus calls Himself 'the Good Shepherd' (John 10:11), connecting these traditions. It hints at divinely unified teaching, entrusted through leaders.

verses.text: My son, beware of anything beyond these. Of making many books there is no end, and much study is a weariness of the flesh.
verses.comment: While study is good, the inspired word brings certainty that endless human speculation cannot. This sets apart divinely preserved wisdom from sheer intellectual pursuit and mirrors deference to established tradition.

verses.text: The end of the matter; all has been heard. Fear God and keep his commandments, for this is the whole duty of man.
verses.comment: The summary of human purpose—fear God and keep His commandments—reflects both moral law and an implicit trust in God’s authority. Obedience and reverence, put together, signal a holistic spiritual life.

verses.text: For God will bring every deed into judgment, with every secret thing, whether good or evil.
verses.comment: A direct teaching about final judgment, which Jesus also affirms (cf. Matt. 12:36; John 5:28–29). Both the literal expectation of judgment and its spiritual implications motivate believers to strive for holiness until the end.
